dialog.text: What is the 'inherited wound' everyone talks about? Why does it feel like it follows me everywhere?
dialog.instructions: young boy voice; curious, slightly shaky; soft tone; moderate pace; vulnerable intonation

dialog.text: Imagine a seed planted generations ago — fear, shame, a whisper that 'you are not enough.' That seed grows into a shadow that walks beside you, repeating the old script.
dialog.instructions: teacher voice (shadow); deep, calm, warm; slow measured pace; slight echo for weight; compassionate tone

dialog.text: So... it's not really mine? Then why do I feel guilty or defensive all the time?
dialog.instructions: boy; puzzled, hopeful; a little quicker; rising intonation at the end

dialog.text: It wasn't chosen by you; it was handed down through stories, reactions, and silence. Not your fault — but it asks to be noticed. Healing is learning to be the gardener, not the victim, of your inner landscape.
dialog.instructions: shadow; gentle firmness; steady cadence; reassuring warmth

dialog.text: I'm afraid if I look too close I'll break things — hurt people, or myself.
Looking isn't breaking. Start small: notice the trigger, name the feeling, allow the sensation without acting. Treat the shadow as a messenger — ask it what it needs instead of fighting it.
dialog.instructions: shadow; calm, instructional; measured pace; nurturing tone

dialog.text: Name it... like saying aloud 'I'm scared of being left' — does that actually help?
dialog.instructions: boy; tentative, quiet; low volume; hopeful curiosity

dialog.text: Yes. Naming brings light. Then listen. Often the wound wants safety, a voice, or to be seen. When you give attention, it stops shouting through your actions.
dialog.instructions: shadow; warm encouragement; steady, soft emphasis on 'listen' and 'seen'

dialog.text: I did that once — I said, 'I see you' to my panic. It softened. But how does that become real freedom?
dialog.instructions: boy; surprised, softer; breathy relief in tone

dialog.text: Freedom isn't removing the shadow; it's changing your response. Each time you choose presence over reaction, you rewrite the inherited script. Small rewrites become a new lineage.
dialog.instructions: shadow; resonant, slightly uplifting; deliberate pace; clear enunciation

dialog.text: So if I heal little by little, I won't pass the same wound on to someone else?
dialog.instructions: boy; growing confidence, hopeful; quicker toward the end

dialog.text: Exactly. Your inner work becomes the inheritance you gift forward: courage instead of fear, calm instead of reactivity, choice instead of habit. The shadow learns to be an ally.
dialog.instructions: shadow; warm triumph, calm; smiling tone; conclusive pace

dialog.text: Tonight, sit with one memory or one feeling. Name it, speak to the shadow, and share one sentence of what you learned in the comments — your insight could start someone else's healing.
dialog.instructions: shadow; inviting, gentle smile in voice; slow, closing cadence; soft encouragement to act
